text: Welcome to my channel, The English Grammar Doctor. Today I want to tell you a story. A story about a man, a very old
man. He has no luck. He has no fish.
People laugh at him, but he never gives up. This story is simple, but it can change your life. Because sometimes the
biggest battles are inside us. Do you feel like you try but nothing works?
Comment below. Do you feel that too? The old man lived near the sea. Every morning before the sun was up, he walked
to his small wooden boat. His boat was old. His fishing lines were old. His sail had many holes and was patched with
old cloth. Some people laughed and said his boat looks like his face full of lines. But the old man didn't listen. He
was quiet. He didn't speak much. He didn't complain. He just walked to the sea. He was not weak. His body was thin
but strong. His skin was brown from the sun. His hands were full of cuts and old scars. Those scars were not from today.
They were from many years of catching big fish. He had strength but no luck.
For 84 days he caught nothing. Not one fish, not even a small one. On some days he saw big fish swimming under his boat,
but they did not take the bait. He waited. He hoped, but he returned home with nothing. The people in his village
started to say, "He is finished. He will never catch another fish again." But the old man still believed. He said to
himself, "Each day is a new day. The sea can change in one moment." He looked at the sea like a friend. He called it
Lamar in Spanish. The way people talk about a woman they love. The sea was not just water for him. It was his life. It
was his battle. It was also his hope.
There was one boy. The boy's name was Manolan. He was not the old man's son.
But he loved him like a father.
When the boy was 5 years old, the old man took him out on the boat. He learned to fish from him. He learned to hold the
line, to wait with patience, to feel the sea. They had many good days together.
But after 40 days without a fish, the boy's parents said, "He has no luck. Go fish with someone else." And the boy
listened. He was sad, but he obeyed. On the other boat, the boy helped catch big fish. On the first day, they caught
three good ones. The boy's parents were happy, but the boy was not. His heart stayed with the old man. Every day when
the old man returned with an empty boat, the boy waited for him. He helped him carry the lines, the sail, and the small
wooden box. They didn't speak much, but they understood each other. One evening, the boy said, "I want to fish with you
again." The old man smiled and said, "You are on a lucky boat now. Stay there. Do not worry about me." The boy looked down. I don't care about luck. I
care about you. You taught me everything. The old man looked at the boy with kind eyes. I know, but this is how life is. Sometimes we must do what
we don't like. The boy nodded. He felt the truth, but his heart still wanted to go back to the sea with the old man.
They sat together on the terrace, a small open cafe near the water. Other fishermen were there. Some made jokes about the old man. Some were quiet. The
older men respected him. They remembered when he was young and strong. They knew he once caught the biggest fish anyone
had seen. They did not laugh. They talked about the wind and the sea, about the fish and the weather. But their eyes
watched the old man. They saw more than his thin body. They saw his strength, not in muscles, but in spirit. The boy
and the old man drank a cold beer. They watched the sky. It was getting dark.
The sea was calm. "Tomorrow will be a good day," the old man said. "Yes," the boy answered. "I will get your bait and I will bring you some sardines."
The old man said, "I can do it. You should go play baseball. I can still row. I can still fish." The boy smiled.
I want to help. And I will get the sardines and I will bring four fresh baits, too. The old man asked. You didn't steal them, right? The boy
laughed. No, I bought them, but I would steal them for you. The old man laughed, too. Thank you. You are already a man.
That night, they walked to the old man's house. It was a small shack made of palm leaves. There was only one room. It had
a bed, a table, a chair, and a place to cook with charcoal. There used to be a photo of the old man's wife, but he took
it down. It made him too sad. Now it was hidden under his clean shirt on the shelf. The boy asked, "Do you have food?" The old man smiled. "Yes, I have
rice and fish, but there was no food. It was only a story. They made this story every night." The boy said, "Do you want
me to make a fire?" The old man said, "No, I will eat later, or I will eat it cold." They both knew there was nothing,
but they smiled. The boy said, "85 is a lucky number." The old man said, "Yes, tomorrow is the 85th day. Maybe I will
catch one that weighs 1,000 lb." The boy nodded. I will keep your sardines cold.
We can share them in the morning. The old man said, "The Yankees cannot lose." The boy laughed. But I fear the Indians
of Cleveland. The old man said, "Have faith in Deaggio." The boy said, "Do you think we can buy a lottery ticket with
the number 85?" The old man thought for a second. "Maybe, but we need money.
First you borrow, then you beg." The boy said, "I will borrow the money. Don't worry. The old man looked at the boy and
smiled. You are good. Go now. Tomorrow is a new day, a big day. The boy said, "Good night, old man." The old man said,
"Sleep well, my son." He sat by the door and looked at the sea. His heart was quiet, but his spirit was ready.
Tomorrow he would go far, far out into the sea, where no one else would go. The evening was quiet. The sun was low. The
sky turned from yellow to pink and then to dark blue. The sea was calm. The wind was soft. The boats were back. Some
boats had big fish. Some had small fish.
The old man's boat had nothing. No fish, no luck. But still, he looked calm. He tied his boat. He carried the sail. He
walked slowly. His legs were tired. His back hurt, but he did not show it. The boy was waiting. Like every evening, he
helped the old man. He took the fishing lines. He took the box. He carried the gaff and the harpoon. He did not say
much. He just walked beside the old man.
The other fisherman talked and laughed.
Some looked at the old man. Some laughed at him. Some felt sad but said nothing.
The old man did not look at them. His eyes looked at the sea. His steps were slow, but he walked like a man who still
had a dream. The boy wanted to say something, but he waited. He looked at the old man's face. The face had many lines. It looked tired. But the eyes,
the eyes still had light, still had life. The boy thought, "He is old, but he is not broken. He still has a dream in his heart."
They reached the small house. It was made of dry palm leaves. Inside there was only one room. There was a bed, a table, a chair, and a small place to
cook. Now he kept it under his clean shirt on the shelf. He looked at it sometimes, but not tonight. Tonight he was thinking about the sea. The boy
placed the gear on the floor. The old man leaned the mast against the wall.
The room was silent, but their silence was warm. It was not cold. The boy asked, "Do you have food?" The old man
smiled and said, "Yes, I have some rice and fish." But there was no rice, no fish, no food. The boy knew that. The
old man knew that. But they played the same story every night. It was not a lie. It was a way to keep hope. The boy
said, "Do you want me to make the fire?" The old man said, "No, maybe I will eat the rice cold." The boy smiled. They
both knew the truth, but the game helped them feel strong. The night came slowly.
The old man sat by the door. The boy said, "I will get the sardines, and I will bring four baits." The old man said, "I have two." I put them in salt.
The boy said, "But I will bring fresh ones." The old man looked at him. "You didn't steal them, right?" The boy smiled. "No, I bought them, but I would
steal for you." The old man said, "Thank you. You are already a man." The boy asked, "Do you remember the first time
you took me in the boat?" The old man laughed. Yes, you were five and I caught a big fish. It was too strong. It broke
the boat. It almost killed you. The boy said, "I remember the noise. I remember you threw me into the front. I remember
the smell of blood. I was not afraid. I was happy." The old man looked at him. I told you that story many times. Maybe
you remember because I told you. The boy said, "No, I remember everything from the first day. You are my teacher." The
old man looked at the boy with eyes full of love. "If you were my son, I would take you out tomorrow. But you have your
parents. They want you to fish on the lucky boat." The boy said, "Yes, but my heart is with you." The boy said, "I
will go now and get the sardines." The old man nodded. Go, my son. Tomorrow will be a big day. The boy walked away.
The old man sat alone. He watched the sea. He could not see the sea, but he could feel it. He sat quietly. The wind
touched his face. His eyes looked far.
Then he stood up. He went to his bed. He rolled up his pants and used them as a pillow. He covered himself with an old
blanket. He closed his eyes. The room was dark, but in his mind there was light. He did not dream of fish. He did
not dream of his wife. He did not dream of the sea. He dreamed of lions. Yes, lions. Golden lions running on a white
beach. He saw them every night. They played like children. They ran in the sand. He loved the lions. They were strong. They were free.
They reminded him of something from long ago. When he was young, when he had power, when he had dreams.
He smiled in his sleep. The lions were there. They were not afraid. They did not need luck. They were simply there,
proud and wild and beautiful. The boy came back. He saw the old man sleeping.
He did not wake him. He took a blanket and put it over his shoulders. He looked at the old man's face. It was full of
lines, but it was peaceful. His hands were open. His breath was slow. The boy sat near the door. He said nothing. He
just sat. He felt quiet. He felt proud.
He looked at the stars and he thought, "Tomorrow will be different." The sea was waiting. The fish were waiting. And
the old man, the man with no fish, he was dreaming of lions. It was still dark. The sky had no color. The village
was asleep, but the old man was awake.
He opened his eyes and listened. It was quiet. Only the wind moved outside.
The sea was calling him. He could feel it in his bones. He sat up slowly. His body hurt. His back was stiff. His hands
felt weak, but he did not complain. This was normal. This was life. He stood, rolled up his blanket, and put on his pants. The room was cold. The air
smelled of the sea. He looked at the little table, the chair, and the pictures on the wall. He looked at the shelf where he kept his wife's photo
under his clean shirt. He didn't take it out. Not today. He knew today would be important. Today might be the day. The
day he catches the big one. The day he becomes lucky again. He whispered 85.
A lucky number. Then he opened the door and stepped outside into the dark morning. He walked to the boy's house.
The boy was still sleeping. The door was not locked. The old man walked in slowly. His feet made no sound. He saw the boy sleeping on a small bed. He
walked to him, touched his foot and waited. The boy opened his eyes and saw the old man. He did not speak. He just got up and put on his clothes. They
walked together without talking. The road was quiet. Other men were also walking with their fishing gear. No one spoke much. They were all tired. They
were all thinking of the sea. The boy carried the lines and the harpoon. The old man carried the mast and sail. The
wood felt heavy on his shoulder, but he said nothing. They walked to the beach where the small boat waited. The boat
looked small against the dark sea, but the old man did not feel fear. He only felt calm. The boy said, "Do you want
coffee?" The old man nodded. "We will put the gear in the boat first." They placed everything carefully. The boy ran
off to get the coffee. He brought it in an old tin can. It was hot and strong.
The old man drank it slowly. He said, "This will be the only thing I drink today." The boy said, "I will get your sardines." The old man nodded again.
"You are a good boy." The boy smiled and ran off again. The old man sat on the side of the boat and looked at the sea.
It was still too dark to see clearly, but he knew it was out there waiting deep, full of mystery, full of life. He
did not hate the sea. He loved it. But he also knew it could be cruel. The sea was not a friend and not an enemy. It was something more, something big,
something powerful. He had spent his life on the sea, and today he would go far, farther than before.
The boy returned with the bait wrapped in newspaper. He handed it to the old man. Good luck, he said. The old man nodded and smiled.
Good luck to you, too. The boy helped him push the boat into the water. Then he stood and watched as the old man got
in and began to row. The boy stood on the shore for a long time, looking out.
The boat grew smaller and smaller in the dark water. The boy did not move. He only watched. He believed in the old man. He believed today would be
different.
The old man rode. He did not hurry. He moved slowly with care. The sea was dark and soft. The boat made little noise.
The stars were still in the sky. He rode far, farther than other boats. He wanted to go where no one else went, where the
big fish waited. His hands moved the oars like they had done for years. His arms pulled the boat forward. He was old, but he still had strength. He did
not look back. He looked ahead. Always ahead. The sky slowly changed. A little light touched the water. The stars began
to fade. The sea changed color. First gray, then blue. The old man smiled. He felt ready. Today was different. He
could feel it in the air, in the water, in his bones. He reached the deep part of the sea. He called it the great well.
It was a place where fish came together.
He saw birds flying low. He saw flying fish jump out of the water. He saw seaweed floating near the boat. He knew this was a good sign. He dropped his
lines into the water. One line went 40 fathoms down. Another went 60, another at 100, and one at 125. Each line was
perfect. Each hook was hidden with fresh sardines. The bait looked real. It smelled sweet. It was placed with care.
The old man looked at the lines. They stood straight in the water. He watched them. He waited. He listened. He felt
the sea. He said nothing but inside his heart he was speaking. Come big fish, come and find me. I am here. I am ready.
The sun was rising now. It touched the sea like gold. The boat rocked gently.
The lines were quiet, but the old man knew this was the moment. This was the new day, a new chance. He was far from
land, alone with the sea. But he was not afraid. He was full of hope. He did not feel old now. He felt alive. He felt
strong. He watched the sea. He watched the sky. And he waited for his chance.
His heartbeat slowly. His hands were ready. His mind was calm. This was the life he had chosen. This was his place, his sea, his dream. And maybe today
would be the day. The old man was now far out on the water. The land was behind him. He could not see the shore anymore. But he was not worried. This
was his sea. This was where he felt at home. The boat moved gently on the water. The waves were soft. The sky was
wide and blue. The sun was warm on his back. The air smelled clean. The sea was deep, very deep. a quiet dark blue that
went down forever. It looked peaceful, but the old man knew this water could hide big things, strong things, beautiful and dangerous things. He loved
the sea. He called her Lamar, like a woman, kind, wild, mysterious. Some fishermen called it Elmar, like a man.
But to him, the sea was soft. The sea was a partner, sometimes a lover, sometimes a mother, sometimes a fighter, but never a stranger. He looked down
into the water. The light touched the surface and danced like gold. The deep water below was full of life. Tiny fish
swam near the boat. They moved like silver rain. He saw jellyfish with long purple threads. He saw flying fish jump
and glide above the surface like little birds. He saw the thin yellow lines of saraso weed floating slowly past. These
were all signs, signs that fish were near. The old man watched everything.
The sea was talking and he listened. A bird flew above the boat, small and black. It looked down at the water. It
circled and cried. The old man smiled.
He said quietly, "You're looking, too.
You're hunting just like me. His hands touched the fishing lines. He checked them one by one. They were strong, clean, perfect. Each hook had been
prepared with care. Each sardine was fresh and sweet. He had set four lines at four different depths. One line went
deep. One stayed near the middle. Two were closer to the surface. He did not trust luck. He trusted preparation. The
lines did not move yet, but he waited.
He always waited. He did not rush the sea. The sea worked in her own time. He sat quietly in the boat. The sun rose
higher. His face was warm. His eyes were narrow from the light. He did not mind.
This was his world. The boat, the sun, the sky, the sea, and the dream of a fish.
The hours passed. The boat floated gently. The lines hung still. Nothing pulled, but he was not sad. He was not bored. He looked out and smiled.
It is only the beginning, he said softly. The fish will come. He drank some water from his bottle. He looked at the sky. The clouds were light. No
storms, only wind, light, and the long day ahead.
The boat moved with the current. The old man rode a little, just enough to keep the lines straight. He did not want the
bait to move. He wanted the fish to find it, to think it was real. That was the secret, to wait, to be quiet, to not
scare the sea. He watched the seabirds.
They flew low. They looked for bait fish. He followed their path with his eyes. He saw them dive into the water.
He watched the ripples. Sometimes a school of fish pushed to the surface.
Sometimes a splash meant something big was below. The old man watched it all.
He was like a part of the sea. A shadow on the water. A patient hunter. He said, "Show yourself. I am ready." Still the
lines did not move. Still the sea was silent. But the old man smiled. "Maybe you are deep," he said. "Maybe you are watching me, too. He remembered his
younger days. He remembered the sound of the line pulling fast, the fight, the power, the fish that jumped into the
air, the fish that pulled the boat for hours. He remembered the feel of the rope burning into his hands, the pain, the pride, the wind. He missed those
days. But he was still here. Still strong enough to row, strong enough to hope. He had lost many things in life.
Friends, money, time, but not this. Not the sea, and not the dream. That was still inside him, stronger than before.
The sun was now high. The heat touched his skin. He took off his hat and wiped his forehead. He looked into the blue
water again. It was calm, silent, full of mystery. He leaned over the side of the boat. He could see deep, very deep.
The water changed from blue to purple to black. It felt like looking into space.
"You are beautiful," he whispered to the sea. "And today you will give me something. I feel it." He sat again, quiet, ready. The boat rocked softly.
The line stayed still. But the moment was close. He could feel it. He looked at the bird again. It flew far now into
the sky. It was alone. Just like him. He watched it go. Just like him. He watched it go. Then he looked down again. His
hands touched the lines. His eyes scanned the water, his heartbeat slow but strong. This was the deep blue sea.
And this was his place. He was not afraid. He was not tired. He was one with the ocean. He did not need a crowd.
He did not need applause. He only needed a fish. And the sea would give him one.
One fish, one chance. That was enough.
Chapter 5. The fish takes the bait. The sun was high now. The sea was shining.
The water was flat. The sky was clean.
The boat moved slowly with the wind. The old man sat quietly. He watched his lines. He checked them again and again.
He touched them gently with his fingers.
He waited. He was calm. He was patient.
He was not thinking of food. He was not thinking of pain. He was thinking of the fish. Somewhere down there, deep under
the boat, the fish was swimming. He did not know when. He did not know how, but he felt it. He felt that something big
was near. He could feel it in the rope.
He could feel it in the air. It was not noise.
It was not movement. It was something else. A sense, a whisper from the sea.
He said nothing, but inside he was awake, alive. Every part of him was ready.
Then it happened. Just a small touch, very soft, on the line. The old man felt it with his fingers. It was not strong.
It was not fast. Just a little change in the rope, like a breath, like a blink.
He stopped moving. He held his hand still.
He waited.
His eyes looked at the water. Nothing moved, but the feelings stayed. Then it came again. A soft pull. The line moved
a little. Then it stopped. Then it moved again. The old man smiled.
But he did not speak. He had seen this before. The fish was near. It was smelling the bait. It was touching it gently. It was not sure yet. The old man
said in a quiet voice, "Come, fish. Take your time. I have waited many days. I can wait some more." The fish did not
take it yet. It was smart. It was big.
It was strong. It was careful. The old man felt another soft pull, a second, a third. The fish was tasting the sardines. It was near the hook, but it
was slow. The old man's fingers were like soft feathers. He let the line move. He did not pull. He did not show tension. He let the fish feel nothing.
No fear, no weight. Just sweet, soft bait floating in the deep blue water.
The fish circled the bait again. The old man whispered, "Eat it, my friend. Eat it all. Take the whole thing. Then I
will know you and you will know me." And then it happened. The fish took the bait. The line moved faster now, but the
old man still held it soft. He let it slide through his fingers. He let the fish swim with it. He did not pull. He did not shout. He did not fight. Not
yet. The fish swam deep, very deep. It did not rush. It was not afraid. It took the bait sideways in its mouth. The old
man knew this moment. He had lived it many times in the past, but this time it was different. This fish was bigger.
This fish was older. This fish was stronger.
And this fish was his test, his chance, his mountain to climb.
The old man let the line go. Slowly, carefully, it slipped between his thumb and finger. The fish swam deeper. The boat rocked a little. The water
whispered under the sun. The old man reached for the reserve coils. He tied them together. He checked the knots. He breathed slowly. He said, "Not yet.
Wait. Let him eat it well." The fish slowed down. The line was tight now, but not too tight. The old man knew the
right moment. He had missed it before, but not today. Today he would be perfect. He would not be early. He would
not be late. He would be exact. Then the line pulled hard, strong, deep, heavy.
The fish was swimming with the bait in its mouth. The fish was his now. The old man pulled back with both hands. He
stood up and used all his strength. He pulled hard, once, twice, again. The rope burned his hands. The boat jumped.
The sea splashed. The line went tight like a wire. The fight began. The old man shouted, "Now we start." The boat
moved. The fish pulled. It did not jump.
It did not rush. It just pulled deep, heavy. The boat moved with it. Slowly out to sea, far from the shore. The old
man leaned back. He let the fish pull.
He did not try to stop it. Not yet. He needed time. He needed to understand this fish. The line cut into his back.
His hands were red, but he smiled. "You are big," he said. "You are strong, but so am I." The boat moved farther. The
sun dropped lower. The sky turned gold.
The sea was quiet. But the line was tight. The fish was still pulling. The old man braced his body. His arms shook.
His back hurt. But he held on. I will not let go, he whispered. No matter how far you go. Chapter 6. Pulled by a giant. The fish was not small. It was
not weak. It was a giant. The old man knew it now. This was no ordinary catch.
This fish was a fighter. This fish was full of strength. It pulled and pulled.
The line was tight like steel. The old man sat low in the boat. His hands held the line. His back leaned against the
wood. He could not rest. He could not move much. His arms were tired. But he did not give up. The fish was pulling
him into the deep sea, far from land, far from help. But he did not fear. He smiled to himself. "If you want to pull,
then pull," he said softly. "I will go with you wherever you take me. I will not stop.
The boat moved slowly, very slowly, over the wide blue water. The sun was still in the sky. The wind was soft, but inside there was a storm. A storm of
strength, a storm of silence, a storm between the man and the fish. The fish did not jump. It did not shake the line.
It just swam deep. It pulled with power, with patience, like a big boat under the sea. The old man felt it in his bones.
This fish was smart. This fish was careful. It did not waste energy. It did not play. It just moved forward farther
and farther. You are like me, said the old man. You do not fight fast. You fight slow. You use time. You use silence. He liked the fish. He respected
it. It was an equal, a worthy enemy and also a friend. Yes, a friend. Because in this great sea, only the two of them
were alive in this fight alone. No one else. Just the man, the fish, and the ocean around them. His hands hurt. The
rope had made small cuts in his skin.
Blood came out. The salt water touched the wounds. It stung. But he did not cry. He did not complain. He had seen worse. He had felt worse. This was
nothing. This was part of the journey.
He moved the rope slowly, carefully to another part of his hand. He shifted his body. He breathed. He had to save
energy. He had to think clear. He had to be ready because the real fight was not just in the arms. It was in the heart.
It was in the mind. The one who stayed calm would win. The one who stayed awake, who stayed smart, who stayed focused, that one would win. And he
wanted to win. Not just for food, not just for the fish, but for himself, for the boy, for the dream.
Hours passed. The boat was now far from land. The old man looked back. He saw nothing, only water. only waves. The
land was gone, but he felt no fear. He felt peace. He whispered, "I've gone too far before. I will return again." He
looked at the sky. The clouds were soft.
The sun was low. The evening was near.
But the fish kept swimming, and the old man kept holding. The sea was quiet. The boat was small. But the fight was great.
Bigger than most men ever know. Bigger than a story. Bigger than a day. This was the kind of fight that changes you.
He remembered other fights long ago when he was young, when he was strong. He remembered a contest in a cafe, a hand
wrestling match. It lasted one full day all night until morning. People watched, people cheered, but he said nothing. He
just held the hand of the other man. He did not move. He did not blink. He waited. And in the end, the other man gave up. He won. Not with fast moves,
not with noise, but with quiet power.
This was the same. This was that fight again. But now his opponent was the sea and the fish.
The stars began to shine. The sky turned dark. The moon came slowly. The old man was tired. But he did not sleep. He
could not. The rope was in his hand. If he slept, he might lose it. And if he lost the line, he lost the fish. And if
he lost the fish, he lost everything. So he stayed awake. He drank water. He chewed a little piece of tuna. It was
not much, but it helped. He talked to himself. He whispered to the fish. You are strong, he said. But I will hold. I
am old. Yes, but I am not finished. The boat moved in the night. The fish swam deep. The rope stayed tight. The sea was
black now, silent, full of stars above and darkness below. But still, the old man did not let go. He smiled in the
dark. He whispered, "We are one now. You pull, I hold. We are together in this dance." His back was tired, his legs
were stiff, his arms were shaking, but his mind was clear. His heart was calm, his spirit was awake. This was his
mountain. This was his test. And he was ready for more. Chapter 7. Alone with the ocean night had come. The sea was
black. The stars were shining. The moon was soft in the sky. The old man sat alone in his small boat. The rope was
still tight in his hand. The fish was still pulling slowly in the deep water.
The boat moved little by little. There was no sound but the sea. No voice, no bird, only the wind and the quiet rhythm
of the waves. He was tired, but he was not done. He was hurting, but he was not broken. His hands were cut. His arms
were stiff. His back was sore, but he held the rope with care. He talked to the fish in his heart. He said, "I am
still with you, big one. I am not going anywhere. I will stay with you. I am your brother and we are not finished.
The old man had been awake since morning. Now it was deep night. He had not slept. He had not rested. But he did not feel lonely. He did not feel fear.
He had the sea with him. The stars were above him. The great fish was under him.
He was not alone. He was part of something big. The world was quiet. But his mind was full. He thought about the boy. He saw his face. He heard his
voice. The boy would be worried. But the old man could not stop now. He whispered, "Don't worry, boy. I am still strong. I will come back. I will not
lose this fish. I will not lose myself." He looked at the stars again. He knew the stars. They were old friends. He had
watched them all his life. They helped him find his way. They helped him dream.
He thought, "The fish is under me. The stars are above me, and I am in the middle. I am the line between the sea and the sky." He smiled. His smile was
tired, but real. He had nothing but his boat, his line, his hands, and his will.
